3. Describe siege weapons: trebuchet, battering ram, siege tower, catapult.
4. Describe castle defenses: murder holes, portcullis, arrow loops, hot oil.
5. Discuss the siege dilemma: attackers could wait months; defenders could starve.
6. The child designs siege weapons or defensive improvements.
7. Record in history journal.
materials_needed: Images of siege weapons and castle defenses

slides.heading: Castle Sieges
slides.subheading: Attack and Defense in Medieval Warfare
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into medieval castles! It tells us we're going to learn about something called "Castle Sieges," which means how armies tried to get into castles and how the people inside tried to stop them. It's going to be like a big game of tag, but with really big rocks and strong walls!

items: Images of trebuchets, battering rams, siege towers, and castle defensive features
Drawing materials for siege weapon or defense design
slides.setup_instructions: Display images of siege weapons alongside castle defensive features. If possible, show a diagram of a siege in progress. Have drawing materials ready for the design activity.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our castle mission! We've got pictures of giant catapults called trebuchets, big logs called battering rams, and tall towers on wheels called siege towers – those were the attackers' toys. Then we have our history journal and pencil, and some drawing stuff for when we get to design our own amazing inventions!

slides.text: Castles were built to be almost impossible to capture. But armies kept inventing new ways to attack! This back-and-forth between attack and defense drove castle design for 500 years. When someone invented a better weapon, castle builders invented a better defense. Let us explore both sides.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part tells us how castles were super tough to get into, but armies were always trying to find new ways to break in. Think of it like when you build a super strong fort, and your friend tries to find a way to sneak in! For hundreds of years, people kept making better attacking weapons and then castle builders made even better defenses to stop them.

slides.text: SIEGE WEAPONS — to attack castles: The TREBUCHET was a giant catapult that could hurl 300-pound stones over castle walls (the most powerful siege weapon!). The BATTERING RAM was a huge log swung at gates. SIEGE TOWERS were rolling wooden towers as tall as the walls — soldiers climbed inside and crossed to the walls on top. CATAPULTS launched smaller stones and even disease-ridden material (an early form of biological warfare!).
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for some amazing attacking machines! The trebuchet was like a giant arm that could fling huge rocks way over the castle walls – imagine throwing a boulder! A battering ram was a giant log used to smash down the gates. Siege towers were like rolling skyscrapers that let soldiers climb right onto the castle walls. And catapults were used to throw smaller things, sometimes even yucky stuff to make the defenders sick!

slides.text: CASTLE DEFENSES — to resist siege: MURDER HOLES were openings above the gate passage where defenders dropped boiling water or rocks on attackers entering below. The PORTCULLIS was a heavy iron gate that dropped to block entry. MACHICOLATIONS were stone platforms that jutted out from walls, allowing defenders to drop things on attackers at the base. CONCENTRIC CASTLES had walls within walls — if attackers breached the outer wall, they faced another wall inside!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's talk about how the castles fought back! See those holes above the gate? Those are murder holes where defenders could drop rocks or hot liquid on anyone trying to get in. The portcullis was like a giant metal curtain that could slam down to block the entrance. And some castles were built with walls inside walls, so even if attackers got through one wall, they still had another one to fight!

slides.text: The biggest threat in a siege was not weapons but TIME. Armies would surround the castle and WAIT. If they cut off food supplies, the castle would eventually starve. Some sieges lasted MONTHS or even years! Castle builders responded by digging deep wells, stockpiling food, and building secret escape tunnels. The longest siege in history lasted 3 years!
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is about a super sneaky trick armies used: waiting! Instead of fighting hard, they would just surround the castle and wait for the people inside to run out of food and water. It's like playing a waiting game where the other person gets hungry and has to give up. This is why castles needed wells for water and lots of food stored up!

slides.prompt: In your history journal, draw and label at least 3 siege weapons AND 3 castle defensive features. Then choose one side: Are you the ATTACKER or DEFENDER? Design either a new siege weapon or a new castle defense improvement. Draw your invention, label its parts, and explain how it works. Write a paragraph describing a siege from your perspective (attacker or defender).
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to be super creative! Grab your journal and pencil, and look at those pictures of the weapons and defenses. First, draw at least three of the attacking weapons and three of the castle defenses, and label them so we know what they are. Then, pick if you want to be an attacker or a defender, and design your very own super-secret weapon or defense! Draw it, tell us what it's called, and how it works.

slides.text: Medieval siege warfare shows the endless cycle of invention: every new attack created a new defense, and every defense inspired a new attack. This pattern continues today in many fields — technology, sports, business. Understanding this cycle helps us see that problems always lead to solutions, which lead to new problems. That is how human ingenuity works!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name 3 siege weapons and 3 defensive features and explain the siege strategy of starving a castle?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You explored how attacking and defending castles was like a game of invention, where one idea always led to another. It's pretty amazing how people kept thinking up new ways to solve problems, isn't it? This pattern of inventing and improving happens all the time, even today, helping us make cool new things!

parent_notes: Siege warfare is dramatic and engaging, especially for children who enjoy strategy and engineering. The trebuchet in particular captures children's imagination — there are many YouTube videos showing working reconstructions. If your child enjoys this topic, building a small trebuchet from popsicle sticks is an excellent STEM project. The attack-defense cycle is a powerful thinking framework that applies to many areas of life. Balance the military content with the human cost — sieges were devastating for civilians inside castles, especially peasants who had taken refuge.

title: Climate Zones — How Climate Affects Plant and Animal Life
description: Students explore how climate zones determine which plants and animals can survive in different regions, creating distinct biomes. They study tropical rainforests, temperate forests, and tundra as examples of climate-biome connections.
instructions:
1. Review the three climate zones from Day 1.
2. Introduce biomes: large regions defined by climate and living things.
3. Tropical biome: dense vegetation, incredible biodiversity.
4. Temperate biome: deciduous forests, grasslands, moderate diversity.
5. Polar biome: tundra, few species but highly adapted.
6. Connect: why do polar bears not live in tropical forests?
7. The child creates a biome comparison chart.
8. Record in geography journal.
materials_needed: Images of tropical, temperate, and polar biomes

slides.heading: Climate and Biomes
slides.subheading: How Climate Shapes Life on Earth
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing our big topic for today: climate and biomes! It's like a title page that tells us we're going to learn how the weather and temperature in different parts of the world shape the kinds of plants and animals that can live there. It’s like how you can only wear certain clothes when it’s cold outside, right?

items: Images of tropical rainforests, temperate forests, and arctic tundra
slides.setup_instructions: Display the biome map alongside the climate zone map from Day 1. Gather dramatic images of each biome showing characteristic plants and animals.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is our materials slide, like a treasure map for what we need! We've got a world map showing all the different biomes, which are like big neighborhoods for plants and animals. We also have some super cool pictures of rainforests, forests, and the icy tundra, and we’ll need drawing paper, colored pencils, and your geography journal to record everything. Your grown-up can help you gather all these exciting things!

slides.text: Climate zones do not just determine weather — they determine WHAT CAN LIVE THERE! A BIOME is a large region with specific climate, plants, and animals that have adapted to those conditions. Tropical climates create rainforest biomes. Temperate climates create forest and grassland biomes. Polar climates create tundra biomes.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide explains what a biome is! Think of it as a giant home for plants and animals that all share the same kind of weather, like being hot and rainy all the time or cold and snowy. The slide tells us that different climate zones create different biomes: tropical climates mean rainforests, temperate climates mean forests and grasslands, and polar climates mean the freezing tundra. It's all about what the climate allows to live there!

slides.text: TROPICAL BIOMES (near equator): Hot and wet year-round. Result: the most diverse life on Earth! Rainforests have layers of plants from giant trees to tiny mosses. Animals: monkeys, toucans, jaguars, tree frogs, millions of insects. Over HALF of all species on Earth live in tropical biomes!
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to visit the tropics! This slide shows us the tropical biome, which is super hot and gets lots of rain all year long, just like a giant greenhouse. Because it's so warm and wet, it has the MOST different kinds of plants and animals on Earth – like monkeys swinging in trees and colorful birds! Over half of all the living things on our planet live in these amazing rainforests.

slides.text: TEMPERATE BIOMES (middle latitudes): Four seasons with moderate temperatures. DECIDUOUS forests have trees that lose leaves in fall (oak, maple, beech). Animals: deer, bears, foxes, squirrels, songbirds. These forests change dramatically through the seasons — green in summer, golden in fall, bare in winter, budding in spring.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're heading to the temperate biome, which is like our neighborhood with four seasons! It's not too hot and not too cold, and the trees here are special because they lose their leaves in the fall, like the oak and maple trees you might see. You’ll find animals like deer and bears here, and these forests look totally different in every season, from green and leafy to bare and snowy.

slides.text: POLAR BIOMES (near poles): Extremely cold, with frozen ground (permafrost). The TUNDRA has no trees — only low shrubs, mosses, and lichens that survive the harsh conditions. Animals: polar bears, arctic foxes, caribou, snowy owls. Every species here has special adaptations: thick fur, fat layers, color changes for camouflage.
slides.mascot_explanation: Brrr, this is the polar biome, also called the tundra! It's way up north or south near the poles, and it's freezing cold with snow and ice, and the ground is even frozen underneath! There aren't any tall trees here, just small bushes and mosses that can handle the chill, and the animals like polar bears and arctic foxes have special thick fur to stay warm. They are super tough!

slides.prompt: Create a biome comparison chart with three columns: Tropical, Temperate, and Polar. For each biome, include: climate description, 3 plants, 3 animals, a description of the landscape, and a small illustration. Then answer: Why cannot a polar bear survive in a tropical rainforest? Why cannot a toucan survive in the tundra? Write at least 3 sentences explaining how animals are adapted to their climate zones.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the scientist and artist! You'll use the map and pictures to fill out a chart comparing the tropical, temperate, and polar biomes, drawing what they look like and listing some plants and animals. Then, you'll answer some super interesting questions about why animals can only live in certain places, like why a polar bear wouldn't like the hot rainforest! You've got this!

slides.text: Climate shapes EVERYTHING about life in a region — from the tallest trees to the smallest insects. Organisms evolve to fit their climate over thousands of years, which is why each biome has unique species found nowhere else. Protecting biomes means protecting the incredible diversity of life that climate has created!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child connect climate zones to biomes, name characteristic plants and animals of each, and explain why organisms are adapted to specific climates?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we learned so much today! This last slide reminds us how amazing nature is and how perfectly plants and animals fit into their homes, called biomes, because of the climate. It's like they've been specially designed for their weather over thousands of years! You did a fantastic job comparing the biomes and thinking about how life fits its environment.

parent_notes: The climate-biome connection is one of the most important ecological concepts. Children who understand this relationship see the natural world differently — they understand WHY different places have different life forms. The adaptation discussion (why polar bears have thick fur, why tropical plants have huge leaves) builds scientific thinking. If your child is interested in a particular biome, encourage independent research — biome studies are rich projects that integrate geography, science, art, and writing. Consider creating a biome diorama in a shoebox for a hands-on extension.

title: Read Aloud — The Cricket in Times Square, Chapters 1-4
description: Begin George Selden's 'The Cricket in Times Square,' a story about Chester the cricket who arrives in New York City from Connecticut. Students discuss setting, friendship between unlikely characters, and the magic of an unfamiliar place.
instructions:
1. Introduce the book and author George Selden.
2. Read chapters 1-4 aloud.
3. Discuss the setting: Times Square subway station in 1960s New York.
4. Meet the characters: Chester Cricket, Tucker Mouse, Harry Cat, Mario.
5. Discuss: How does Chester feel in a strange new place?
6. Compare this to Ramona's feelings about new situations.
7. The child draws the newsstand setting and writes about the characters.
materials_needed: The Cricket in Times Square by George Selden

slides.heading: The Cricket in Times Square
slides.subheading: Chapters 1-4: A Cricket in New York City
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of a book! It tells us the title of the story we're about to read, "The Cricket in Times Square," and that we'll be reading the first few chapters, from 1 to 4. It's like getting ready for an exciting adventure!

items: The Cricket in Times Square by George Selden
slides.setup_instructions: This book has a completely different tone from Ramona — it is whimsical and gentle, featuring talking animals in a realistic setting. Read with warmth. Use different voices: Chester is earnest, Tucker is fast-talking and enthusiastic, Harry is calm and wise.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this part, we need to get our tools ready for learning. We have the book itself, which is like our treasure map for the story. We also need a reading journal, which is a special notebook for our thoughts, and some pencils and colored pencils so we can draw and write down all the cool things we discover.

slides.text: We are starting a very different kind of story! 'The Cricket in Times Square' is about Chester, a cricket from the quiet countryside of Connecticut, who accidentally ends up in the busiest place in the world: the Times Square subway station in New York City! He makes friends with Tucker Mouse and Harry Cat.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like meeting our new friends! The story is about a little cricket named Chester who comes all the way from a quiet place to the super busy Times Square in New York City. He's going to meet a clever mouse named Tucker and a cool cat named Harry, and they're going to become friends, even though cats usually chase mice and crickets!

slides.text: Notice the SETTING — George Selden describes Times Square in amazing detail: the noise, the crowds, the neon lights, the rumble of subway trains. For Chester, coming from a peaceful meadow, this is overwhelming! Think about a time YOU were somewhere completely new and different. How did it feel?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think about where this story takes place. The book talks all about Times Square, which is a really loud, busy, and exciting place with lots of flashing lights and rumbling trains. Imagine how different that is from a quiet meadow – that's how Chester feels! Can you think of a time you went somewhere totally new and it felt a little bit strange or overwhelming, just like Chester?

slides.text: The friendships in this book are between very UNLIKELY characters: a cricket, a mouse, and a cat! In real life, a cat would eat both a cricket and a mouse. But in this story, friendship crosses boundaries. Pay attention to how Tucker and Harry welcome Chester — what do good friends do when someone is new and scared?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we think about what makes a good friend. Chester, Tucker, and Harry are such different animals, but they become friends anyway! We need to pay close attention to how Tucker and Harry help Chester when he's feeling scared and lost in the big city. What kind of things do you think good friends do for each other, especially when one of them is new?

slides.prompt: In your reading journal, draw Mario's newsstand in the subway station (use details from the book!). Create character cards for Chester, Tucker, and Harry: name, animal, personality traits (at least 3 each), and what they think about Times Square. Write a prediction: How will Chester's musical talent change his life? What adventures will he have?
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to get creative! In your journal, you get to draw the newsstand where Mario works, using the details from the book to make it look just right. Then, you'll make special "character cards" for Chester, Tucker, and Harry, writing down what they're like and how they feel about being in Times Square. Finally, make a guess about what amazing things Chester's music might do in the city!

slides.text: The Cricket in Times Square is about finding home in unexpected places and friendship between creatures who are very different from each other. Chester has a special gift — his musical chirping. Great stories often feature characters who have unique talents that change their world. Let us find out what happens when Chester's music meets New York City!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe the setting and main characters, identify the theme of friendship between unlikely characters, and make predictions?
slides.mascot_explanation: We've reached the end of our first part of the story, and we learned that this book is all about finding a home and making friends in surprising places, even when you're very different. Chester has a super special talent with his music, and great stories always show how unique gifts can change everything. We'll find out what happens when Chester's chirping meets the big city!

parent_notes: The Cricket in Times Square is a gentle, charming book that appeals to children who love animals, music, and friendship stories. The 1960s New York City setting is historical for today's children, offering opportunities to discuss how cities have changed. Tucker Mouse is a scene-stealer — his fast-talking personality is fun to voice. The theme of finding beauty (Chester's music) in an overwhelming urban setting resonates with many children. If your child loved James and the Giant Peach but is less engaged by realistic fiction, this book bridges the gap with its talking animals in a real setting.

title: Spelling and Vocabulary — Latin and Greek Roots
description: Students are introduced to the concept that many English words come from Latin and Greek roots. They learn common roots (aud = hear, vis = see, port = carry, graph = write) and discover how knowing roots helps decode unfamiliar words.
instructions:
1. Discuss: English borrows words from many languages, especially Latin and Greek.
2. Present root 'aud' (hear): audience, audio, auditorium.
3. Present root 'vis/vid' (see): visible, video, vision.
4. Present root 'port' (carry): transport, portable, export.
5. Present root 'graph' (write): autograph, biography, photograph.
6. The child builds word families from each root.
7. Try to decode unfamiliar words using root knowledge.

slides.heading: Latin and Greek Roots
slides.subheading: The Building Blocks of English Words
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of a cool book! It's showing us that we're going to learn about special word parts called "Latin and Greek Roots," and how they help us understand a lot of the words we use in English every day. Think of them like the secret building blocks of our language!

items: Root word cards: aud (hear), vis/vid (see), port (carry), graph/gram (write)
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare root cards with the root, meaning, and 3-4 example words. Create a word family chart for each root. Have a dictionary available for exploring additional words.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our detective gear ready! We've got these special cards here with our "root" words on them, like 'aud' which means 'hear'. We also have a chart where we'll write down words that use these roots, and our special language journal and pencil. Oh, and a dictionary – that's a big book full of word meanings that will help us check our work!

slides.text: Here is a SUPERPOWER for reading and spelling: many English words are built from ROOTS — word parts that came from Latin and Greek thousands of years ago. If you know the root, you can figure out the meaning of words you have NEVER seen before! Let us learn four powerful roots today.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is giving us a super cool secret for reading and spelling! It's telling us that lots of English words are built from smaller word parts called "roots," which come from ancient languages like Latin and Greek. If we learn what these roots mean, we can unlock the meaning of new words we've never seen before, just like having a secret code!

slides.text: Root AUD means HEAR (from Latin). AUDIENCE: people who come to HEAR. AUDIO: related to HEARING (audio book = a book you HEAR). AUDITORIUM: a place for HEARING (concerts, speeches). AUDIBLE: able to be HEARD. If you see 'aud' in a word, it is about hearing!
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to learn about the root 'AUD'! This one comes from Latin, and it means HEAR. So, when you see 'aud' in a word, it's probably about hearing something. For example, an 'audience' is a group of people who *hear* a show, and an 'auditorium' is a place where people gather to *hear* music or a speaker.

slides.text: Root VIS/VID means SEE (from Latin). VISIBLE: able to be SEEN. VISION: the ability to SEE. VIDEO: something you SEE (recorded images). INVISIBLE: NOT able to be seen (in + visible). Root PORT means CARRY (from Latin). TRANSPORT: CARRY across. PORTABLE: able to be CARRIED. EXPORT: CARRY out of a country.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're learning two more super important roots! 'VIS' or 'VID' means SEE, like in the word 'visible' which means you can SEE it, or 'video' which is something you SEE. Then we have 'PORT,' which means CARRY. So, if you 'transport' something, you CARRY it from one place to another, and a 'portable' item is something easy to CARRY.

slides.text: Root GRAPH means WRITE (from Greek). AUTOGRAPH: writing by oneself (auto = self). BIOGRAPHY: writing about a life (bio = life). PHOTOGRAPH: writing with light (photo = light). GEOGRAPHY: writing about the earth (geo = earth)! Even our school subject names use Greek roots!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is another cool root from an ancient language called Greek! 'GRAPH' means WRITE. So, an 'autograph' is when someone writes their name, and a 'biography' is writing all about someone's life. Even 'geography,' which is what we study in school about the Earth, uses this root because it's like "writing about the Earth"!

slides.prompt: Create a word family chart for each root. For AUD, VIS, PORT, and GRAPH, list at least 3 words containing that root and explain how the root's meaning connects to the word's meaning. Then try to decode these words using root knowledge: 'inaudible' (in + aud + ible), 'television' (tele + vis + ion), 'import' (im + port). Write a sentence for each root using one of its words.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to put on our word detective hats and do some building! You'll take those root cards and write down other words that use them on your chart, like how 'aud' means hear and 'audience' uses it. Then, try to figure out what words like 'inaudible' or 'television' mean by using the root meanings we just learned, and write a cool sentence using one of the words!

slides.text: Knowing Latin and Greek roots is like having a SECRET DECODER for English! Over 60% of English words have Latin or Greek roots. When you encounter an unfamiliar word, look for a root you recognize — it will often give you enough meaning to understand the word. We will learn more roots throughout the year. You are becoming a word detective!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define 4 Latin/Greek roots, give examples of words containing each, and use root knowledge to decode an unfamiliar word?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You learned that knowing Latin and Greek roots is like having a secret decoder ring for English words. It's super helpful because so many words use them, and now you can figure out what new words mean just by looking for those root parts. You're officially a word detective, and we'll learn even more roots next time!

parent_notes: Latin and Greek roots are one of the most powerful vocabulary-building tools available. Research shows that teaching roots dramatically improves reading comprehension because children can decode unfamiliar words independently. Start with these four roots and add more gradually (tele = far, bio = life, auto = self, phon = sound, aqua = water). Make it a game: when you encounter a new word, challenge the child to find its root. This skill pays dividends for years — SAT vocabulary, science terminology, and legal/medical terms all rely on Latin and Greek roots.

title: Quarter 2 Math Review — Operations and Fractions
description: Students review all major math concepts from Quarter 2: multi-digit subtraction with borrowing, multiplication facts, introduction to division, fractions, and measurement. They complete a comprehensive practice set and identify areas needing more work.
instructions:
1. Warm up with skip counting: 3s, 4s, 6s.
2. Review subtraction with borrowing (2 problems).
3. Review multiplication and division facts (mixed flash cards).
4. Review fractions: compare, add, subtract with circles.
5. Review measurement: measure 2 objects in inches and centimeters.
6. Complete a comprehensive practice set.
7. Identify areas of strength and areas to improve.
8. Create a study plan for challenging topics.

slides.heading: Quarter 2 Math Review
slides.subheading: Celebrating How Much You Have Learned!
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like a party banner for our math adventure today! It's called "Quarter 2 Math Review," and it means we're going to look back at all the super cool math stuff we learned in the last few months and celebrate how much smarter we've gotten. Isn't it exciting to see all the new things you can do with numbers now?

items: Mixed multiplication and division flash cards
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a mixed practice set covering all Q2 topics: 2 subtraction with borrowing, 5 multiplication, 3 division, 3 fraction problems, and 2 measurement tasks. Have fraction circles and ruler available. This is a review, not a test — the goal is to identify strengths and areas for growth.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the tools we need for our math review. We've got our math journal and pencil for writing down our answers, special fraction circles that help us see parts of a whole, a ruler to measure things in inches and centimeters, and flash cards with multiplication and division problems. You'll also need that practice sheet with all the problems we're going to solve. Go grab all these things, and let's get ready!

slides.text: Let us celebrate everything you have learned in Quarter 2! You have mastered so many skills: subtraction with borrowing (even 3-digit!), multiplication facts (3s, 4s, 6s), introduction to division, fractions (comparing, adding, subtracting), and measurement (inches, centimeters, feet, yards). That is incredible progress!
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like a cheerleader for you! It's reminding you of all the amazing math skills you learned in Quarter 2. Think about it – you learned how to subtract bigger numbers by borrowing, you got super speedy with multiplication facts, you even started learning about division, and you can now compare, add, and subtract fractions, plus measure things! That's a whole lot of brain power you've built up!

slides.text: Today we review each topic. For each problem, try your best. If something feels easy, that is a STRENGTH — celebrate it! If something feels hard, that is an area for GROWTH — we will work on it more. There are no grades, just useful information about where you are.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is telling us how to think about our review today. It wants us to try our best on every problem. If a problem feels easy peasy, that's fantastic – it means you're strong in that area, and you should feel proud! If a problem feels a little tricky, that's okay too; it just means it's a chance for you to grow and learn even more, kind of like practicing a new skill.

slides.text: Tips for the review: Subtraction — line up your columns and work right to left. Multiplication — use strategies (doubling for 4s, 5+1 for 6s). Division — think multiplication! Fractions — use the circles if you need them. Measurement — start at zero on the ruler.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are some helpful hints for tackling the math problems. For subtraction, remember to line up your numbers carefully and always start from the right side. When you multiply, think about cool tricks like doubling numbers to help you. And for division, it's like a secret code – if you know your multiplication, you can unlock division! Don't forget to start measuring right at the zero mark on your ruler.

slides.prompt: Complete the review set: 1) 534 - 278, 2) 403 - 167, 3) 6 x 8, 4) 4 x 9, 5) 3 x 7, 6) 24 ÷ 6, 7) 36 ÷ 4, 8) 21 ÷ 3, 9) Compare: 2/3 ___ 3/4, 10) 2/5 + 1/5, 11) 5/6 - 2/6, 12) Measure your pencil in inches AND centimeters. After finishing, mark each problem: star for 'I got this!' and circle for 'I need more practice.' Count your stars — that is your strength score!
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to show off your math skills! This is where you'll solve all the practice problems, like subtracting bigger numbers, figuring out multiplication and division facts, comparing and adding fractions, and measuring your pencil. After you finish each one, give it a star if you feel confident, or a circle if you'd like more practice. Counting your stars will show us what you're super good at!

slides.text: Look at how much you know! At the beginning of the quarter, you could not borrow in subtraction, did not know the 3s table, had never divided, and had not worked with fractions. Now you can do ALL of those things! Every challenge you identified is something we will strengthen in Quarter 3. Learning is a journey, and you are making amazing progress.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child demonstrate competence in at least 4 of 5 Q2 math topics (subtraction, multiplication, division, fractions, measurement)?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all you've accomplished! Remember when some of these math ideas seemed really new and tricky? Now you can do them! Every problem you marked for extra practice is just a stepping stone to becoming even more amazing at math. You've made incredible progress, and we'll keep building on this awesome foundation in Quarter 3!

parent_notes: End-of-quarter reviews help both child and parent see the big picture of progress. Frame this as a celebration, not a test. Emphasize strengths: 'You got 10 out of 12! Look how much you know!' For areas needing work, be specific and reassuring: 'Division with remainders needs a bit more practice — we will keep working on it.' Use the results to plan Q3 practice: if fractions are strong, maintain them; if subtraction borrowing is shaky, build in more practice. The visual record (stars vs. circles) makes progress tangible and motivating.

title: Sound — Pitch and Volume
description: Students explore how pitch (high/low) and volume (loud/soft) are created. They discover that pitch depends on vibration speed (frequency) and volume depends on vibration size (amplitude), using instruments and experiments to demonstrate.
instructions:
1. Review: sound is caused by vibrations.
2. Introduce PITCH: how high or low a sound is.
3. Demonstrate: shorter/thinner objects vibrate faster = higher pitch.
4. Rubber band guitar: compare thin and thick bands.
5. Water bottle xylophone: more water = lower pitch.
6. Introduce VOLUME: how loud or soft a sound is.
7. Demonstrate: bigger vibrations = louder sound (hit drum hard vs. soft).
8. Record observations.
materials_needed: Water bottles (5-6, filled to different levels)

slides.heading: Pitch and Volume
slides.subheading: The High and Low, Loud and Soft of Sound
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like a title page for our sound adventure! It's introducing us to two important things about sounds: pitch, which is how high or low a sound is, and volume, which is how loud or soft it is. Think about a tiny mouse squeaking – that's a high pitch, and a lion roaring – that's a low pitch!

items: Rubber band guitar with bands of different thicknesses
5-6 identical glass bottles filled with different amounts of water
Wooden mallet, spoon, or stick for tapping bottles
Drum or pot for volume experiments
slides.setup_instructions: Fill bottles with increasing amounts of water (empty, 1/4, 1/2, 3/4, full). Line them up. Have the rubber band guitar from the vibration lesson. Clear space on a table for the ruler experiment.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our experiments today. We have a special rubber band guitar, some glass bottles that we'll fill with different amounts of water to make sounds, a little stick to tap them with, a drum for making loud and soft noises, and even a ruler! You'll also need your science journal and a pencil to write down what you discover, so go grab all these things with a grown-up's help!

slides.text: All sounds have two main qualities: PITCH (how high or low) and VOLUME (how loud or soft). A bird chirping is high pitch. A drum booming is low pitch. A whisper is low volume. A shout is high volume. Today we discover what CAUSES these differences — and it all comes back to vibrations!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important idea to remember: all sounds start with vibrations, which are like tiny shakes or wiggles. Pitch tells us if a sound is high like a bird or low like a tuba, and volume tells us if it's loud like a shout or soft like a whisper. Today, we're going to figure out exactly *why* some sounds are high and others are low, or loud and soft!

slides.text: PITCH depends on how FAST something vibrates (called FREQUENCY). Fast vibrations = high pitch. Slow vibrations = low pitch. Experiment: extend a ruler off the edge of the table. Twang the short end (just 3 inches sticking out): HIGH pitch! Fast vibrations! Twang a long end (10 inches out): LOW pitch! Slow vibrations!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to explore pitch! This step says that pitch has to do with how *fast* something wiggles. If something wiggles really fast, it makes a high sound, and if it wiggles slower, it makes a low sound. To try this, take your ruler and stick part of it off the edge of the table, then give it a little flick – listen to the sound, and then try sticking more of the ruler off and flicking it again to hear the difference!

slides.text: The water bottle xylophone shows the same thing! Tap each bottle. The one with the MOST water makes a LOW sound (more water vibrates slowly). The EMPTY bottle makes a HIGH sound (less water, air vibrates fast). You can tune the bottles by adding or removing water to play a scale!
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide talks about our water bottle xylophone! When you tap the bottles, the one with the most water will make a low sound because the water makes it wiggle more slowly, and the empty bottle will make a high sound because the air inside wiggles super fast. See if you can tap them all and figure out which one makes the highest sound and which makes the lowest!

slides.text: VOLUME depends on how BIG the vibrations are (called AMPLITUDE). Hit the drum gently: soft sound, small vibrations. Hit it HARD: loud sound, BIG vibrations. Same pitch, different volume! You can feel the difference: touch the drum after a gentle tap vs. a hard hit. The hard hit vibrations are much stronger.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is all about VOLUME! It tells us that volume depends on how *big* the wiggles are. If you hit the drum very gently, you'll make a soft sound with small wiggles, but if you hit it hard, you'll make a loud sound with big wiggles! Try tapping the drum softly and then hard, and you can even put your hand on it to feel how much bigger the wiggles are when it's loud!

slides.prompt: Conduct three experiments and record results: 1) Ruler twang: measure how much ruler extends off the table for high, medium, and low pitch. 2) Water bottles: tap each bottle and rank from lowest to highest pitch. Draw the water levels. 3) Drum volume: tap gently, medium, and hard. Describe the volume and vibration size for each. Create a chart: 'Fast vibrations = ___ pitch' and 'Big vibrations = ___ volume.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for some awesome experiments! You'll get to measure how much of the ruler hangs off the table for different sounds, listen to your water bottle xylophone and draw how much water is in each one, and describe the sounds and wiggles from tapping the drum. Then, you'll fill in some charts to show what you learned about fast wiggles making high sounds and big wiggles making loud sounds!

slides.text: Now you understand the science behind every sound: pitch comes from vibration SPEED (frequency), and volume comes from vibration SIZE (amplitude). This is how musical instruments work — a violin player changes pitch by pressing strings at different lengths, and changes volume by bowing harder or softer. Sound is beautiful physics!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the relationship between vibration speed and pitch, vibration size and volume, and demonstrate both concepts experimentally?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You figured out the secrets of sound – how fast wiggles make high and low pitches, and how big wiggles make loud and soft volumes. It's like learning how a guitar or a drum works, and it's all because of those amazing vibrations! You're basically a sound scientist now!

parent_notes: The ruler experiment is particularly effective because children can see the vibrations, hear the pitch change, and control the variable (how much ruler extends). The water bottle xylophone can become a real musical instrument — with patience, you can tune it to play a simple scale. Volume and amplitude are often confused by adults and children alike — emphasize that volume is about the SIZE of vibrations, not the speed. Connect to the recorder: covering more holes (longer air column) makes lower pitch. Blowing harder makes louder, not higher!

title: Making Musical Instruments — Sound Science Meets Art
description: Students design and build simple musical instruments using household materials, applying their knowledge of pitch and volume from science class. They create at least two instruments and compose a short piece to perform.
instructions:
1. Review how pitch and volume work.
2. Present instrument categories: strings, percussion, wind.
3. Design instrument 1: a string instrument (rubber band guitar or shoebox harp).
4. Design instrument 2: a percussion instrument (shaker, drum, water xylophone).
5. Optional instrument 3: a wind instrument (straw oboe or bottle whistle).
6. Test and tune each instrument.
7. Compose a short piece using the instruments.
8. Perform!

slides.heading: Homemade Instruments
slides.subheading: Where Sound Science Meets Musical Creativity
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this first slide! It's like a secret invitation to become a sound scientist and an artist all at once. We're going to make our very own musical instruments, and it's going to be super fun and super smart!

items: Rubber bands of various sizes, open box (string instrument)
Plastic containers with lids, rice/beans/beads (percussion shaker)
5-6 water bottles at different levels (water xylophone)
Tape, cardboard tubes, and other craft supplies
slides.setup_instructions: Set up three instrument-building stations with materials organized. Have completed examples if possible. Test each instrument design in advance to ensure they work. Cover workspace for messy activities.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we need to gather for our instrument-making adventure. We've got rubber bands for stretchy sounds, boxes and containers for making noise, rice and beans to shake, water bottles to make a watery tune, and even straws for blowing! You'll need to find a grown-up to help you collect these things.

slides.text: You learned that sound comes from vibrations, pitch from vibration speed, and volume from vibration size. Now let us BUILD instruments that demonstrate these principles! There are three families of instruments: STRINGS (vibrating strings), PERCUSSION (vibrating surfaces or objects), and WIND (vibrating air).
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like our science reminder! Remember how we learned that wiggling things make sound? Well, these instruments are going to show us exactly that! We're going to learn about three main kinds of instruments: ones with strings you pluck, ones you hit or shake, and ones you blow into.

slides.text: STRING INSTRUMENT: Stretch rubber bands of different thicknesses across an open box. Thicker bands vibrate slower (lower pitch), thinner bands vibrate faster (higher pitch). Pluck them to play! You can also change pitch by pressing down on a band to shorten the vibrating length.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to make a string instrument! See this box and these rubber bands? We're going to stretch the rubber bands across the box, and when you pluck them, they'll wiggle and make sounds. Thinner rubber bands will wiggle faster and make a higher sound, and thicker ones will wiggle slower for a lower sound – just like magic!

slides.text: PERCUSSION INSTRUMENT: Fill a small container with rice or beans and seal it — shake for sound! More filling = different sound. Or use the water bottle xylophone from science. WIND INSTRUMENT: Flatten one end of a straw and cut it into a V-shape. Blow through the V — the straw vibrates and makes a buzzing sound! Cut the straw shorter for higher pitch.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the percussion and wind instruments! For a shaker, we just put some rice or beans inside a container and close it tight – shake it and listen to the rhythm! For a wind instrument, we'll snip a straw in a special way and blow on it to make a buzzing sound, and cutting it shorter will make the sound go higher!

slides.prompt: Build at least 2 instruments from different families. Test each one: Can you change the PITCH (higher and lower)? Can you change the VOLUME (louder and softer)? Label the science on each instrument in your music journal. Then compose a short piece using your instruments — at least 8 beats with a rhythm pattern. Name your composition and perform it!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the builder and the performer! Your mission is to make at least two instruments from different groups, like a string and a shaker. Then, test them out to see if you can make high and low sounds and loud and soft sounds, and write down what you discover. Finally, you’ll put on a mini-concert for us!

slides.text: You are now both a scientist and a musician! Every instrument ever invented — from a prehistoric bone flute to a modern synthesizer — works on the same principles: vibrations creating sound waves. When you understand the science, you can create music from ANYTHING. Some of the world's greatest music has been made on simple, handmade instruments!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build instruments from at least 2 families, explain the science behind how they produce different pitches and volumes, and perform a short composition?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You became a super scientist and musician today by making your own instruments! Think about it – every instrument you've ever heard, from a big drum to a tiny whistle, works on the same science of wiggling things. You've learned that you can make music from almost anything!

parent_notes: This lesson brilliantly connects science and music. The instrument-building is engaging for all learning styles: kinesthetic (building), auditory (testing sounds), visual (seeing vibrations). The straw oboe can be tricky — the key is cutting a clean V-shape and applying steady, gentle air pressure. Not every instrument will sound beautiful, and that is fine — the learning is in the building and testing. If the child is particularly creative, this can become an extended project: building a full set of instruments and forming a 'one-person band.' Celebrate the composition by recording it on a phone!

title: Plant Care Update and Herb Harvest
description: Students check on their herb garden planted in week 16, measuring growth, recording observations, and harvesting any herbs that are ready. They learn about sustainable harvesting and use fresh herbs in a simple recipe.
instructions:
1. Visit the herb garden.
2. Measure plant height with a ruler.
3. Observe: leaf count, color, health.
4. Discuss what the plants needed and got (or did not get).
5. If herbs are ready, demonstrate how to harvest: cut just above a leaf node.
6. Use fresh herbs in a simple recipe (herb butter or herb water).
7. Plan continued care.
8. Update the plant observation journal.

slides.heading: Herb Garden Update
slides.subheading: Measuring Growth and First Harvest
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our plant adventure today! It tells us we're going to check on our herb garden that we planted a little while ago, measure how much they've grown, and maybe even pick some herbs for the first time. It’s exciting to see how our little plants are doing!

items: Plant observation journal or science journal
Softened butter, small bowl, bread for herb butter
Pencil and colored pencils for drawings
slides.setup_instructions: Bring the herb garden to the work area. Have measuring tools ready. If herbs have not sprouted or have died, prepare to discuss what went wrong and replant. If herbs are thriving, prepare herb butter ingredients.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our supplies ready for our plant investigation! We'll need our herb plants, a ruler to measure them, a special journal to write down what we see, and some clean scissors for snipping herbs. We also need some butter, a bowl, and bread if we're making herb butter, and a pencil and colored pencils for drawing our plants. Make sure you have everything you need before we start!

slides.text: It has been about 2 weeks since we planted our herbs! Let us check on them like scientists. First, OBSERVE: Are the plants alive? What color are the leaves? Are there new leaves since last time? Any problems — yellow leaves, drooping, insects? Write down everything you notice.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to be super-sleuth scientists and look closely at our herb plants! First, we need to observe them – that means looking very carefully. Are they alive and green? Do they have new leaves since we last saw them? We'll write down everything we notice in our journal, like if any leaves look a little sad or if we see any tiny bugs.

slides.text: Now MEASURE: How tall is each plant from the soil to the top? Record the measurement in your journal. Compare to your last measurement. How much has each plant grown? If different herbs grew at different rates, why might that be? Some herbs grow faster than others — basil is speedy, parsley is slow!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we get to measure our plants like real scientists! We'll use the ruler to see how tall each herb is, from the dirt all the way to the very top leaf. Then, we'll write that number down in our journal and see if it's taller than last time. It’s neat to see how much they’ve grown, and some herbs grow faster than others, just like some friends run faster than others!

slides.text: If your herbs are big enough (at least 3-4 inches with multiple leaves), we can HARVEST some! The rule: never take more than one-third of the plant at once. Cut just ABOVE a set of leaves (a leaf node) — this encourages the plant to branch out and grow more. After harvesting, the plant will grow back even bushier!
slides.mascot_explanation: If our herbs are looking big and strong, with plenty of leaves, we get to do something super cool: harvest them! The important rule is to only take a little bit, less than a third of the plant, and to cut right above a set of leaves. This helps the plant grow even more and become nice and bushy. It's like giving the plant a haircut so it can grow back even better!

slides.text: Let us make HERB BUTTER! Chop your harvested herbs finely. Mix into softened butter with a pinch of salt. Spread on bread and taste. YOU grew this herb from a tiny seed! The journey from seed to plate is complete. This is the most Montessori moment of all — taking responsibility for growing your own food.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to make some delicious herb butter! We'll take the herbs we just picked and chop them up really, really small. Then, we'll mix them into some soft butter with a tiny bit of salt. We can spread this yummy butter on bread and taste it – how amazing is it that you grew this flavor yourself from a tiny seed?

slides.prompt: Update your plant observation journal: date, height measurement, leaf count, overall health (scale of 1-5), and any problems noticed. Draw each plant as it looks today. If you harvested, write which herbs you picked and how much. Make herb butter and taste it. Write a comparison: How does fresh herb taste compared to dried herbs from a jar? Rate your gardening success and write one thing you would do differently next time.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to fill out our plant journal and make our herb butter! We'll write down today's date, how tall the plants are, how many leaves they have, and how healthy they look. We'll also draw a picture of our plants and write about which herbs we harvested. Then, we'll taste our herb butter and think about how fresh herbs taste different from the ones in jars, and what we learned about taking care of our plants.

slides.text: You grew food from seeds with your own care and attention! This is one of the most fundamental human skills — growing plants to eat. Every civilization in history depended on people who understood how to care for plants. Your herb garden is small, but the knowledge you gained is the same knowledge farmers use to feed the world.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child measure plant growth, record observations scientifically, harvest herbs properly, and reflect on the growing process?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a fantastic job taking care of your herb garden! You learned how to measure, observe, and even harvest your own food, which is something people have done for thousands of years to feed themselves. You helped your plants grow from tiny seeds into something delicious, and that's a super important skill to have!

parent_notes: This follow-up to the planting lesson completes the growing cycle. If the herbs died or failed to sprout, treat it as a learning experience — what went wrong? Too much water? Not enough light? Wrong temperature? Gardening failure is excellent science: forming hypotheses about what happened builds scientific thinking. If the herbs are thriving, the herb butter activity creates a memorable seed-to-table experience. Continue the observation journal weekly — tracking growth over time is real science. Consider expanding the garden with additional herbs or vegetables.

title: Quarter 2 Language Review — Writing Portfolio
description: Students review their best writing from Quarter 2 and select pieces for a writing portfolio. They reflect on their growth as writers, identify their strongest skills, and set goals for Quarter 3.
instructions:
1. Gather all writing from Quarter 2 (journal entries, narratives, poems, reports).
2. Read through each piece — notice improvement over time.
3. Select 3-4 best pieces for the portfolio.
4. Write a brief reflection for each piece: why you chose it, what it shows about your writing.
5. Identify: What is your strongest writing skill? What do you want to improve?
6. Set 2-3 writing goals for Quarter 3.
7. Compile the portfolio.

slides.heading: Writing Portfolio
slides.subheading: Celebrating Your Growth as a Writer
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our special project! It's called a "Writing Portfolio," and it's all about celebrating how much you've grown as a writer. Think of it like a trophy case for all your amazing words!

items: All Quarter 2 writing samples from the language journal
Reflection template (Title, Why I Chose This, What It Shows)
slides.setup_instructions: Gather all writing from Q2: descriptive paragraphs, spelling work, poems, personal narratives, book reports, dialogue exercises, historical perspective writing. Arrange them chronologically so the child can see growth over time. Prepare a portfolio folder.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us everything we need to get started. We've got all your writing from the last few months – like stories, poems, and even things from your language journal. We also need a folder to keep everything neat, a special paper to write some notes, and your trusty journal and pencil.

slides.text: Writers keep PORTFOLIOS — collections of their best work that show growth and skill. Today you become the editor of your own portfolio! Look through everything you wrote in Quarter 2. You will choose your 3-4 BEST pieces — the ones that make you the most proud.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is super fun because you get to be the boss of your writing! We're going to look through all the writing you did in Quarter 2, and you get to pick out your 3 or 4 absolute favorite pieces. These are the ones that really show off how awesome your writing is!

slides.text: As you read through your writing, notice HOW MUCH YOU HAVE IMPROVED! Compare your first piece to your most recent. You probably see: more adjectives and adverbs, compound sentences, better spelling, dialogue, and stronger descriptions. THAT is growth, and you should be proud of every step.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, as you look through your old writing, pay close attention to how much better you've gotten. It's like comparing a tiny seedling to a big plant – you can see all the progress! You'll probably notice you're using more interesting words and making your sentences even stronger.

slides.text: For each piece you select, write a short REFLECTION: the title, why you chose it (What makes it your best work?), and what skill it demonstrates (descriptive writing, dialogue, poetry, historical perspective, etc.). This reflection shows that you understand your own writing strengths.
slides.mascot_explanation: For each piece you picked, you'll write a little note about it. You'll put the title, tell us why you think it's one of your best, and maybe mention what kind of writing it is, like a story or a poem. This helps you think about what makes your writing so great!

slides.text: Finally, set GOALS for Quarter 3. What do you want to get better at? Maybe: 'I want to write longer stories' or 'I want to use more dialogue' or 'I want to spell more words correctly without help.' Good goals are specific and achievable. Write 2-3 goals for the next quarter.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you become a mind-reader for your future self! Think about what you want to be even better at in your writing next time. Maybe you want to write longer stories or use more exciting words. We'll write down 2 or 3 ideas to help you keep improving.

slides.prompt: Review all your Q2 writing. Select your 3-4 best pieces. For each, write a reflection card: Title, Why I Chose It, and What Skill It Shows. Arrange them in your portfolio folder. Then write a 'Writer's Self-Assessment': What is your strongest writing skill? What improved the most this quarter? What are your 2-3 goals for Q3? Decorate your portfolio cover with your name and 'Quarter 2 Writing Portfolio.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is the big activity where we put it all together! You'll pick your best writing, write those special notes for each one, and put them in your portfolio folder. Then, you'll write down what you're best at and what goals you have for next quarter, and maybe even decorate the cover!

slides.text: Your writing portfolio is a record of your growth and achievement. Every professional writer started exactly where you are — learning the basics, practicing, and getting better with each piece. Look at this portfolio whenever you feel stuck or discouraged. It PROVES that you are improving. Quarter 3 is going to be amazing!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child select their best writing, articulate why each piece is strong, identify areas of growth, and set specific writing goals?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at what you've done! Your writing portfolio is like a map showing how far you've traveled as a writer, and it proves you're getting better and better. Keep this safe, because it's proof of how amazing you are, and it will help you be an even better writer in Quarter 3!

parent_notes: The writing portfolio is a powerful tool for building confidence and self-awareness. Children often do not realize how much they have improved until they compare early and late work. The reflection process develops metacognition — thinking about one's own learning. Display the portfolio or share it with grandparents or other family members to validate the child's work. The goal-setting exercise teaches children to take ownership of their learning. Revisit these goals at the start of Q3 and periodically throughout. This is a Montessori approach: the child assesses their own progress rather than being externally graded.

title: Measurement — Area Introduction with Square Units
description: Students are introduced to area as the amount of space inside a flat shape. They cover rectangles with square tiles to count the area in square units and discover the formula: area = length x width.
instructions:
1. Distinguish perimeter (distance around) from area (space inside).
2. Present a rectangle and fill it with square tiles.
3. Count the tiles: that number is the AREA in square units.
4. Notice: counting tiles is the same as multiplying rows by columns.
5. Introduce the formula: Area = length x width.
6. Practice with various rectangles.
7. Connect area to multiplication arrays.

slides.heading: Introduction to Area
slides.subheading: How Much Space Is Inside a Shape?
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our super exciting math book for today! It's introducing us to a new idea called "Area," and it's asking a really cool question: how much space is actually inside a shape. Think about it, we're going to become space detectives for flat shapes!

items: Square tiles (at least 50, all the same size — 1 inch or 1 cm)
Various paper rectangles of different sizes
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare rectangles on paper: 3x4, 5x2, 4x4, 6x3. Have plenty of square tiles. Graph paper helps visualize the grid pattern. Compare a perimeter example to an area example to establish the difference.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, look at all these cool things we need for our adventure! We have these little square tiles – they're like building blocks for measuring. We also have graph paper, which is like a grid, and some paper rectangles already drawn. And don't forget your math journal and pencil to write down all your discoveries, and colored pencils to make them pretty! Go grab all these things with a grown-up's help so we can get started!

slides.text: We learned PERIMETER: the distance AROUND a shape. Today we learn AREA: the space INSIDE a shape. Imagine painting a wall — you need to know the area to buy enough paint. Or tiling a floor — you need to know the area to buy enough tiles. Area tells us how much surface a shape covers.
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we learned about perimeter? That was like walking all the way around the edge of something, right? Well, today we're learning about AREA, which is different! Area is all about the space *inside* the shape, like how much carpet you'd need to cover a floor or how much paint you need for a wall. It tells us how much flat space something takes up.

slides.text: How do we measure area? With SQUARE UNITS! Cover this rectangle with square tiles, fitting them perfectly inside with no gaps and no overlaps. Count the tiles: 12! The area is 12 SQUARE UNITS. If we used 1-inch tiles, we say '12 square inches.' If we used 1-cm tiles, we say '12 square centimeters.'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, how do we find out how much space is inside? We use our square tiles! Your job is to carefully cover the rectangle on the paper with these tiles, making sure they fit snugly together with no empty spots. Once it's all covered, you just count how many tiles you used – that number is the area! If your tiles are 1 inch wide, you say "square inches," or if they are 1 centimeter wide, you say "square centimeters."

slides.text: Look at the tiles inside the rectangle. They form a grid: 3 rows of 4 tiles each. 3 x 4 = 12! That is the area formula: AREA = LENGTH x WIDTH. For a rectangle that is 5 units long and 2 units wide: 5 x 2 = 10 square units. For a square that is 4 x 4: 4 x 4 = 16 square units. Area uses MULTIPLICATION — our old friend!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for a super cool shortcut! See how the tiles make rows and columns, like a checkerboard? You can count them all, or you can be a math whiz and multiply! If a rectangle has 3 rows and each row has 4 tiles, you just do 3 times 4, which equals 12. This gives us the AREA FORMULA: Length times Width! So, for a rectangle that's 5 tiles long and 2 tiles wide, you just do 5 x 2 to get 10 square units. It's like multiplication is our secret key to finding area!

slides.prompt: Find the area of each rectangle: 1) Cover with tiles and count: a 3x5 rectangle (should be 15 sq units). 2) Use the formula: a 6x4 rectangle (6 x 4 = 24 sq units). 3) On graph paper, draw rectangles with areas of exactly 12 square units (how many different rectangles can you make? 1x12, 2x6, 3x4!). 4) Measure a book cover in inches and calculate its area. Compare the PERIMETER and AREA of the same rectangle — they are different numbers!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the area expert! First, cover that 3x5 rectangle with tiles and count them up – you should get 15. Then, use the formula for the 6x4 rectangle; what do you get when you multiply 6 x 4? Next, grab your graph paper and draw some different rectangles that have an area of exactly 12 square units. Finally, measure your book cover and figure out its area using the formula, and then see how different the perimeter number is from the area number!

slides.text: Area and perimeter are related but different! Perimeter measures the EDGE (distance around), and area measures the SPACE INSIDE. Perimeter uses addition; area uses multiplication. Both are essential in the real world: builders need both to construct a house. You now understand both concepts — that is powerful mathematical thinking!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child find the area of a rectangle by counting square units AND by using the formula length x width, and distinguish area from perimeter?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You discovered that area is the space *inside* a shape, and perimeter is the distance *around* it – they're like cousins, related but not the same! You learned how to measure area by counting tiles AND by using the multiplication formula, which is super smart thinking. Builders use both perimeter and area all the time, so you've learned something really useful today!

parent_notes: Area is a natural extension of both measurement and multiplication. The tile-counting approach makes it concrete before introducing the formula. The 'how many rectangles have area 12?' challenge is excellent because it reinforces factor pairs (1x12, 2x6, 3x4) while building area understanding. The area-perimeter distinction often confuses students: perimeter is a length (measured in units like inches) while area is a surface (measured in square units like square inches). Reinforce this distinction whenever possible. Real-world applications abound: how many tiles for the bathroom? How much carpet for the bedroom?

title: The Middle Ages — End of the Era and Bridge to Exploration
description: Students learn about the events that ended the Middle Ages: the Black Death, the Hundred Years War, the printing press, and the fall of Constantinople. They see how these events set the stage for the Age of Exploration in Quarter 3.
instructions:
1. Explain: the Middle Ages ended gradually, not suddenly.
2. Describe the Black Death (1347-1351): killed 1/3 of Europe, changed society.
3. Describe the printing press (1450): Gutenberg's invention spread knowledge.
4. Describe the fall of Constantinople (1453): forced Europeans to find new trade routes.
5. Preview: these changes led to the Age of Exploration!
6. Create a timeline of ending events.
7. Reflect: What was most important about the Middle Ages?
materials_needed: Images of the printing press and medieval events

slides.heading: The End of the Middle Ages
slides.subheading: Events That Changed the World Forever
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the cover of a book! It's called "The End of the Middle Ages," and it tells us that some super important things happened that changed the world and brought a whole era to a close. It’s going to be exciting to learn how!

items: Images of the Black Death, Gutenberg's printing press, and fall of Constantinople
slides.setup_instructions: Mark key dates on the timeline: 1347 (Black Death arrives), 1450 (printing press), 1453 (fall of Constantinople), 1492 (Columbus). Prepare to discuss these events age-appropriately.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our history adventure! We have a timeline that goes way past the Middle Ages, pictures to help us imagine big events, and a special journal with a pencil for writing down our discoveries. Let's make sure we have all of these ready!

slides.text: The Middle Ages lasted about 1,000 years, but three events between 1347 and 1453 changed Europe forever and brought the era to an end. These events were devastating, but they also opened the door to a new age of exploration, science, and art.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide tells us that the Middle Ages didn't just stop all of a sudden, like flipping a switch. Instead, it was like a slow sunset, with a few really big events happening over about 100 years that gradually brought the Middle Ages to a close and opened the door for new adventures.

slides.text: The BLACK DEATH (1347-1351): A terrible disease (plague) swept through Europe, killing about one-third of the entire population — 25 million people! It was carried by fleas on rats. The result was shocking: so many workers died that the survivors could demand better pay and treatment. The feudal system began to crumble because peasants had more power.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready, this one is a bit sad but super important. This slide is about the "Black Death," a really bad sickness that spread through Europe a long, long time ago. It was so serious that it made a lot of people sick and sadly took away many lives, which changed how people lived and worked afterward.

slides.text: The PRINTING PRESS (around 1450): Johannes Gutenberg invented a press with movable metal type. Before this, every book was copied BY HAND (by our friends the monks!). Gutenberg's press could produce hundreds of copies quickly and cheaply. Suddenly, knowledge spread like wildfire! More people could learn to read. Ideas traveled faster than ever.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, this is like magic for books! This slide is about the "printing press," invented by a man named Gutenberg. Before this, people had to write out every single book by hand, which took forever, but his invention let them make lots of copies super fast, spreading stories and knowledge everywhere!

slides.text: The FALL OF CONSTANTINOPLE (1453): Constantinople (modern Istanbul) was the gateway for trade between Europe and Asia. When it fell to the Ottoman Empire, European traders could no longer easily reach Asia for spices, silk, and gold. This forced Europeans to find NEW routes — by sea! This desperate search led directly to the AGE OF EXPLORATION, which we will study in Quarter 3!
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is about a big city called Constantinople and why its "fall" was a big deal. It was like a busy crossroads for traders going between Europe and Asia, but when it was taken over, Europeans had to find totally new ways to get to Asia, which led them to sail across the oceans!

slides.prompt: Create a timeline of the events that ended the Middle Ages: 1347 (Black Death), 1450 (printing press), 1453 (fall of Constantinople), 1492 (Columbus). For each event, draw a small illustration and write 2 sentences explaining its importance. Then write a paragraph: 'The Most Important Thing About the Middle Ages Was...' Choose ONE contribution (cathedrals, guilds, preserved knowledge, etc.) and defend your choice.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to be history detectives! We need to take our timeline and add these big events: the Black Death, the printing press, the fall of Constantinople, and Columbus's trip. For each one, we'll draw a little picture and write two sentences about why it was important, then we'll pick the MOST important thing about the whole Middle Ages for our journal.

slides.text: The Middle Ages gave us cathedrals, universities, guilds, the preservation of ancient knowledge, and the foundations of modern European culture. Its ending — through plague, printing, and trade disruption — created the conditions for the most dramatic era of exploration in human history. Everything is connected! Quarter 3 will take us across the oceans with daring explorers.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe 3 events that ended the Middle Ages and explain how the fall of Constantinople led to the Age of Exploration?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned about some HUGE changes that happened a long, long time ago, like a terrible sickness, a faster way to make books, and a city falling that made people want to explore. All these events together helped start the Age of Exploration, where brave people sailed across the big oceans!

parent_notes: This lesson wraps up the medieval unit and previews the Age of Exploration. The Black Death is a sensitive topic — present it factually and age-appropriately, emphasizing the societal changes it caused rather than dwelling on graphic details. The printing press is one of history's most important inventions; compare it to the internet in terms of knowledge-spreading impact. The connection between Constantinople's fall and the Age of Exploration is crucial: when the land route to Asia closed, Europeans were motivated to find sea routes — leading to Columbus, Magellan, and the dramatic changes of the 1500s.

title: Sound — Musical Instruments and How They Work
description: Students apply their knowledge of sound, pitch, and volume to understand how real musical instruments produce sound. They classify instruments into families (strings, woodwinds, brass, percussion) and explain the science behind each.
instructions:
1. Review: vibrations, pitch (frequency), volume (amplitude).
2. Introduce the four instrument families.
3. Strings: vibrating strings (guitar, violin) — length and thickness affect pitch.
4. Woodwinds: vibrating air column (recorder, flute) — length of tube affects pitch.
5. Brass: vibrating lips + tube (trumpet) — tube length affects pitch.
6. Percussion: vibrating surface (drum, xylophone) — size affects pitch.
7. Classify instruments and explain the science.
8. Record in science journal.
materials_needed: Images of instruments from each family

slides.heading: Musical Instruments
slides.subheading: The Science of Making Music
slides.mascot_explanation: Hey there! This first slide is like the cover page for our exciting music adventure. It tells us we're going to learn all about musical instruments and the cool science that makes them sing, hum, and boom! Get ready to discover how instruments make music and why some sound high and some sound low.

items: Images of instruments: guitar, violin, flute, recorder, trumpet, drum, xylophone, piano
Rubber band guitar from earlier experiments
slides.setup_instructions: Display images of instruments grouped by family. Have the recorder and rubber band guitar available for demonstration. If any family members play instruments, have those available too. Prepare a classification chart template.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's check out what we need for our musical science fun! We've got pictures of lots of instruments to look at, like guitars and drums. We also have a real recorder, which is like a little flute, and a rubber band guitar you might have made before – these will help us see how instruments work. You'll also need your science journal and some colored pencils to draw and write down all the amazing things we discover!

slides.text: Every musical instrument creates sound through VIBRATIONS. But different instruments make different THINGS vibrate! This is how we classify the four instrument FAMILIES: strings (vibrating strings), woodwinds (vibrating air), brass (vibrating lips + air), and percussion (vibrating surfaces).
slides.mascot_explanation: So, here's the super important secret: every single instrument makes sound because something is *vibrating*! Think of a guitar string when you pluck it – it wiggles really fast. This slide tells us that different instruments have different things that vibrate to make their music. We're going to learn about four main groups: strings that vibrate, woodwinds where air vibrates, brass instruments where your lips vibrate, and percussion instruments where surfaces vibrate.

slides.text: STRING INSTRUMENTS: Guitar, violin, cello, harp, piano (yes, piano has strings inside!). Strings vibrate when plucked, bowed, or struck. PITCH changes by: string length (shorter = higher), string thickness (thinner = higher), and string tightness (tighter = higher). Your rubber band guitar demonstrates all three!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's talk about string instruments, like guitars or violins! When you pluck or strum a string, it wiggles back and forth super fast, and that's what makes the sound. If you want a higher sound, you can make the string shorter, thinner, or pull it tighter, just like on that rubber band guitar! It's like the string is singing a higher note when it's stretched or skinny.

slides.text: WOODWIND INSTRUMENTS: Recorder, flute, clarinet, oboe. Air vibrates inside a tube. PITCH changes by changing the length of the vibrating air column — when you cover holes on the recorder, you lengthen the column (lower pitch). When you uncover holes, you shorten it (higher pitch). That is why more fingers down = lower notes!
slides.mascot_explanation: Next up are woodwind instruments, like the recorder or a flute. For these, it's the *air* inside the instrument that vibrates, not the instrument itself! When you blow into a recorder, the air inside starts to wiggle. Covering up the holes makes the air column longer, which makes a lower sound, and uncovering them makes the air column shorter for a higher sound. So, more holes covered means a deeper note!

slides.text: BRASS: Trumpet, trombone, tuba. The player's lips vibrate and the sound is amplified by the metal tube. A trombone changes pitch by sliding the tube longer (lower) or shorter (higher). PERCUSSION: Drums, xylophone, cymbals. Something is struck and vibrates. Bigger drums = lower pitch. Smaller xylophone bars = higher pitch. Same principle as everything else!
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide talks about two more families! Brass instruments, like trumpets, are super cool because your *lips* vibrate against a mouthpiece, and that vibration travels through the long metal tube. Percussion instruments, like drums or xylophones, make noise when you hit them, and the surface starts to vibrate. Bigger drums make a lower sound, and smaller xylophone bars make a higher sound, just like the other instruments!

slides.prompt: Create an instrument classification chart in your science journal. Draw four columns: Strings, Woodwinds, Brass, Percussion. For each family: list 3 instruments, draw one, and explain what vibrates and how pitch is changed. Then answer: 1) Why does a bass guitar sound lower than a regular guitar? 2) Why does covering more holes on a recorder make a lower sound? 3) Why is a tuba lower than a trumpet?
