slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the scientist and musician! In your science journal, you're going to make a special chart with four columns for the instrument families. For each family, list three instruments, draw one, and write down what part vibrates and how they change the pitch. Then, think really hard about those questions to show what you've learned about why different instruments sound the way they do!

slides.text: Every instrument in the world, from a simple drum to a grand piano, works on the same scientific principles: vibrations create sound, vibration speed determines pitch, and vibration size determines volume. Music and science are deeply connected — understanding the physics makes you a better musician, and loving music makes science more beautiful!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child classify instruments into 4 families, explain what vibrates in each, and describe how pitch is changed for 3 different instruments?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You've learned that all music comes from vibrations, and how changing how fast or how big something vibrates changes the sound. From a tiny drum to a giant piano, it all works on the same amazing science principles! Isn't it cool that music and science are best friends? You've become an expert at understanding how instruments make their magical sounds!

parent_notes: This lesson ties together the entire sound unit by applying physics to music. If any family members play instruments, having them demonstrate while the child explains the science is powerful. The piano is interesting because it fits TWO categories: strings (hammers hit strings inside) and percussion (keys are struck). The recorder connection is direct: the child has been changing pitch by covering holes — now they understand the physics behind it. Consider attending a live concert or watching an orchestra performance video to see all four families in action.

title: Quarter 2 Art Showcase — Displaying and Reflecting on Art
description: Students curate a mini art exhibition of their best work from Quarter 2 (Greek pottery, illuminated letters, stained glass, watercolor landscapes, coat of arms). They learn to display art thoughtfully and write artist statements reflecting on their creative journey.
instructions:
1. Gather all art projects from Quarter 2.
2. Select 4-5 best pieces for the exhibition.
3. Create labels: title, medium, date, and a short artist statement.
4. Arrange the exhibition on a wall or table.
5. Write an overall reflection: How has your art improved?
6. Give a gallery tour to family members.
7. Celebrate creative growth!

slides.heading: Quarter 2 Art Showcase
slides.subheading: Your Gallery Exhibition
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the big title for our special art show! It's called the "Quarter 2 Art Showcase," and it means we're going to show off all the amazing art you made in the last few months. Think of it like a museum, but it's all your awesome creations!

items: All Quarter 2 art projects: Greek pottery design, illuminated letter, stained glass window, watercolor landscape, coat of arms, mosaic, any instrument designs
Index cards or small paper for labels
Tape, pushpins, or stands for display
slides.setup_instructions: Gather all art from Q2. Help the child choose a display location: a wall, a table, a shelf. Prepare index cards for labels. Plan the gallery tour — invite family members to attend.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is showing us all the cool art supplies and materials we'll need for our art show. We need all the art you've made, like your Greek pottery, illuminated letters, and more – find them all! You'll also need some index cards and tape or pushpins to make labels and hang them up, and your special journal for writing.

slides.text: Artists display their work in GALLERIES and EXHIBITIONS. Today you curate YOUR OWN art show! A curator selects the best pieces, arranges them thoughtfully, and writes information for viewers. Look through all the art you created this quarter. You have been busy — Greek pottery, illuminated letters, stained glass, watercolors, and more!
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide tells us that today, you get to be an art curator – that's someone super important who decides which art goes in a museum or gallery! You'll look at all the art you've created this quarter, like your Greek pottery designs and those beautiful illuminated letters, and pick out your very best ones to show off.

slides.text: Select your 4-5 BEST pieces. For each one, create a label card with: the TITLE, the MEDIUM (what you used: watercolor, paper, markers), the DATE you made it, and a short ARTIST STATEMENT (1-2 sentences about what inspired you or what you learned making it).
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to choose the stars of our show! You need to pick your 4 or 5 favorite pieces of art. For each one, you'll make a little label that tells people the title, what materials you used (like paint or markers), when you made it, and a short sentence about what inspired you or what you learned.

slides.text: Arrange your exhibition. Group related pieces together (medieval art near medieval history, Greek art near Greek history). Leave space between pieces so each one can be appreciated. Put labels next to or below each piece. Step back and look at the whole exhibition — this represents weeks of creative work!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we make our art show look super professional! You'll arrange your chosen art pieces, maybe putting the Greek art together or the medieval art together. Make sure there's a little space between each artwork so everyone can see it clearly, and then add those labels you made right next to each piece.

slides.mascot_explanation: Time to set up the whole exhibition and get ready to share it! You'll hang everything up and write those labels, and then in your journal, you'll answer some questions about your favorite piece, what you learned, and how your art has gotten even better. After that, you'll be a tour guide for your family, showing them your amazing work!

parent_notes: The art showcase is a meaningful way to end the quarter. It validates the child's creative work, develops communication skills (presenting to an audience), and builds self-reflection habits. Be a genuine, interested audience during the gallery tour — ask questions about the pieces and express specific praise ('I love how you used warm colors in the watercolor' rather than just 'nice job'). Consider photographing the exhibition and the child presenting it. Some families turn this into a tradition: quarterly art shows with refreshments. The artist statement writing connects to language arts skills.
